@Denys Bulakh @Yann Maurer
Well, what about ajax?

First of all we need to upload file, then with ajax we can get progress and success states, and also we can identify wrong codes or duplicates and show it to user, similar to log view when installing something.

For small files, less than 1mb maybe, we don't need log window. For big files we need to split uploaded codes to reasonable chunks, eg. 1k or 5k depends on our own server performance. This way we can show that something still in the progress, chunk by chunk. If process is unfinished we need to keep uploaded file, and we need to show it to user, with text, for example: "There are unfinished coupon codes left. Do you want to rerun?". If codes parsing is completed we can remove uploaded file from server, but would be good to keep track of uploaded files with amount of codes parsed from it, to be able to see what was already uploaded (this is useful for multi-user environment).

References:
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/FileReader
https://developer.mozilla.org/en-US/docs/Web/API/File/Using_files_from_web_applications
https://tutorialzine.com/2013/05/mini-ajax-file-upload-form
https://github.com/pqina/filepond
https://www.dropzonejs.com/

- Adding progress bar to track and show file status
- All the magic with CSS :)

OAuth Authorization with password and refresh_token grants implemented.

Deployment

  1. Deploy the codebase to the server.
  2. Install dependencies via composer: 
    composer install --no-dev
  3. Run migrations using the globally installed phalcon-devtools (or don't use "--no-dev" flag above to install it locally) 
    phalcon migration run
# or locally:
# vendor/bin/phalcon migration run
  4. Adjust the Server configuration as described below.

API Server configuration
Example configuration added to app/config/config.php.example.

  1. Section connectors_auth_methods_map has to be added to app/config/config.php as is.
  2. Section oauth has to be added to app/config/config.php, the following adjustments have to be made:
  • Configure public and private keys:
    • generate Private and Public keys as described at https://oauth2.thephpleague.com/installation/#generating-public-and-private-keys
    • mount the keys to container or put them to server
    • configure the paths to keys on server in app/config/config.php
  • Configure the encryption key:
    • generate encryption key as described at https://oauth2.thephpleague.com/installation/#generating-encryption-keys
    • configure the encryption key in app/config/config.php
  • Adjust the tokens expiration intervals if needed.
  • Generate and put any random client secret for POS client.

Details for client implementation

  • Authorising with password: https://oauth2.thephpleague.com/authorization-server/resource-owner-password-credentials-grant/
  • Refreshing the access token: https://oauth2.thephpleague.com/authorization-server/refresh-token-grant/

Important changes:

  • Composer usage introduced globally for the project. Locally installed dependencies (for Mongo) were merged to global file.
  • Obsolete gyg SDK, tests, controller file, and index file were removed from repository

Out solution for displaying the tickets after redeeming a bundle gift certificate:

Case: We have a Bundle with includes 4 offers and 3 attendees

1. ONE Gift certificate valid for X people
1.1 The user buys the ONE gift certificate for 3 people
1.2 The user redeems the gift certificate
= The user receive 4 PDF for each offer included in the bundle

Why: We can keep the structure which we already have for gift vouchers which include several attendee.

2. 3 Single gift certificates
1.1 The user buys 3 gift certificates for the 3 people
1.2 The user redeems the gift certificates
= The user receive 12 PDF = for each offer and attendee (3*4)

We only create one barcode - not for each offer included in the bundle.
